Prehistoric EMRs Portability Patient Engagement Population Health
Manifesto

Prehistoric EMRs

Medical records systems in healthcare are borderline prehistoric: UI that resembles the Windows 95 era, UX designed with absolutely no consideration of the actual user's workflow, embarassing functionality resulting in more clicks per minute than a game of Minesweeper.

It's no surprise that the majority of physicians exhibit some symptom of burnout. But this will only get worse. With each passing year of newly-graduated medical students, residents, and fellows, we draw nearer to a time in healthcare where providers originated from one of the Gen X, Y or millennial generations. Newsflash, we're all comfortable leveraging technology to get our jobs done, and the majority of us would prefer a mobile solution.

History Tends to Repeat Itself

It should be alarming to the healthcare industry that a significant number of physicians have and are considering leaving the healthcare profession altogether. Partly to blame is the HIT industry standard of accepting horrendous UX. EMRs and CPOE solutions are built to meet the bare minimum regulatory requirements. Nothing more, nothing less, and not until you have to. We're the risk-averse, change-resistant, late-adopting laggards of modern technological solutions.

Interoperability is an embarassing business and political stalwart. Satellite pagers are still the norm. Push notifications have yet to make their entrance. Workflow automation and user-crafted macros are substandard. Mobile-first design is an after-thought. The current burnout of this generation of physicians will only magnify as future generations of physicians skew even more savvy with mHealth solutions.
